Description: Rim and body sherd of Chian black-figured Animal pottery chalice; creamy slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; part of rosette in added red and added white; exterior: at rim, band of dots between dilute lines; below, black-figure decoration consisting of cock (part of head, comb and wattle remaining) to right.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in Stage 4 of the Black Figure Animal Chalice group. Some of the vases in this group have a unique rim pattern. They have filling ornament and the birds featured on the cups are well proportioned and balanced. She also places this sherd in Stage 2 of the Black Figure Animal Chalice Group, all made by the same artist; the composition is well-balanced and the images are precise; incision is used to one model.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 173, p. 331, no. 1595, pl. 204)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 82, no. 22, p. 83, no. 44, pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1302) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
